Destin, this is obviously still a problem, and your advice seems sound. And yet...
I have just spent the last hour trying understand the process and report an obviously freebooted video and got just about nowhere. And multiply that by the number of people who would need to do such a thing to make any difference.

It isn't an easy process. It is not possible (illegal even, in the EU) to report or even suggest obvious copyright infringement unless you yourself own the copyright. So you have to contact the copyright owner. Many of the freeboots (is that the first usage of the plural, btw?) I've seen are of pretty famous people. People who more often than not make it pretty hard work to contact them directly. And will most likely ignore you anyway. Do I want to sign up to "social" media sites just to stand a small chance of being seen by these people? Um; I'd rather not. I'm actually trying to close down on "social" media because I've completely lost faith in it.

Essentially, the problem is the sheer volume of work involved. I don't think this kind of judgement can be automated. Even if it could be, it would then be open to abuse of the system. No; it (currently) needs humans to investigate and correlate and make decisions. And many, many humans to collect the evidence. Resulting in vast amounts of time spent chasing the criminals who most likely have already done the damage. Unless a class action is brought; that might make the required difference, but that is a massive task to organise against such big players.

It's pretty depressing, and I feel deeply for the providers of quality content who are losing out.

The way I'm fighting back is going to be a bit different. I've often seen alternative incomes from things like Patreon or episode sponsors or merchandise e-shops etc. to be 'do this if you want.' And sometimes I've wanted to, and have sponsored people in that way. Some times I've wanted to, but not had the money. Sometimes I've been irritated by the commercialism of it interrupting content.

Now. It costs £150.50 a year for a TV license. And I think I spend about 1/2 of my time watching BBC / bought content, and the other 1/2 watching YouTube. So logically, I owe you guys about £150 a year, right?

I can barely afford that (not working atm), but I'm determined to consciously think about that figure and try my best to meet it if I can.

TLDR: Support the content you like directly. Advert revenue is severely broken.

Excellent video on this insidious problem. I spend thousands of my own money, drive tens of thousands of miles, days at a time out in brutal weather, and dozens of unpaid days off of work each year to capture my videos. I have no sponsors, my video effort is self-funded (mostly by the video revenue). Youtube is an equally guilty party in this saga - I have 700 DMCA takedowns filed already just for Youtube re-uploads of my videos by pirates, many with monetized channels. Youtube has refused to grant me Content ID, meaning I have to manually search for and issue takedowns one-by-one. To add insult to injury, their DMCA form has a 10-submission limit, which I often hit and have to wait to keep sending additional forms. Google is now inserting captcha into every 4 or 5 keyword searches when I try to find infringing videos. The thieves have a streamlined process to upload thousands of videos a day to immediately-monetized channels with no background checks or vetting, while obstacles are continually placed in my way to deal with the problem. I have now spent more time dealing with infringement that I have shooting the original videos on my channel. As a small-time creator, I'm nothing in this fight, and Youtube/Facebook knows it. Like Youtube, Facebook is not likely to grant any content ID system to the little guys, so I expect that without legislation, the small-time creators will continue to get ripped off constantly.

It's getting to the point that the problem is beginning to affect my motivation and drive to create new content. When I'm standing out in a winter storm in subfreezing temperatures for 12 hours, my entire body and camera coated with a layer of ice, I'm thinking "Why am I still out here putting myself through this? It is important to note that a Facebook view and a YouTube view are two very different things. YouTube considers a view to typically count after the ~30 second mark. Facebook's at 3 seconds. Couple that with Facebook's auto-play and you have grossly over-inflated view counts. Facebook's retention, however, is abysmal. What this means is that a typical FB view does not equate to a YouTube one. I'm not saying this in defense of Facebook's actions here, but it is something they will certainly use as in their own defense if any legal recourse is taken to minimize any damages they may have to pay out.

People who are criticizing the sheep analogy because it didn't perfectly demonstrate every single element of the problem need to realise it was just that, an analogy. That's what analogies do. Why? Because that's often their purpose. Analogies are used as a means of simplifying a particular subject in question about certain matters. It is actually quite difficult to formulate an analogy that mirrors every single aspect whilst trying to simplify the matter at the same time. You'll often just end up with a mirrored concept that is unlikely to serve a purpose that demonstrating the original concept might as well have achieved. The only purpose that a mirroring analogy could ever really serve is to make an alien concept familiar and that is obviously not the purpose needing or intending to be served here.
The purpose of the analogy in this case was merely to point out the social injustice and the fact that it is unfair to the creator. To that end, this analogy serves its purpose adequately. The children understood who was the victim, who was the perpetrator and why. It would be gratuitous if one were to try to utilize the analogy into aspects that it wasn't designed for and then criticize when it doesn't work as if it should have. In this case, trying to utilize this analogy to mirror the description of the matter, when it is rather supposed to demonstrate the injustice.

That sheep, was a physical good and that story you told relied on the fact that the sheep had scarcity.

I'm by no means a lawyer. But I do study law and work in an environment that deals - almost on a daily basis - with IP rights. Funnily enough I was to explaining the concept of IP rights v. IP license to a colleague today. IP rights lie with the creator. An IP license allows someone else to use your IP for a fee (or not in the case of FB as you grant it upon accepting the terms) but they don't own your IP. They cannot do what they wish with it. Imagine FB granted a person the license to use their algorithms and that person had someone else copy it and make money off the advertising?! BUT - Here's the issue as I see it: An IP license only applies internationally if the country in which it is used has adequate IP protections. If it doesn't, then you have no ability to license but also no ability to have a legal say in what is done with that IP. So.. the question would be in which countries are these videos being uploaded after being copied from yours (or anyone else's) site? And do those countries have adequate IP protections? Also, Is this a breach of privacy laws for FB to find this out. You also have granted FB a license to use the IP you have provided. So, another question would be what does the term "use" in this context mean? "Use" can mean a wide variety of things: could they modify it, could they duplicate it, could they dispose of it, does it mean they (FB) have to maintain it? If it means they have to maintain it, then should there be a duty of care? By you uploading this IP content onto the FB page and granting them a license to "use", does that mean that if anyone else duplicates this or copies this from the FB website, then they have effectively breached their license? There are holes in this argument I am aware (everything is debatable in court). But I thought I might as well throw my 2 cents worth in seeing as this is an issue I am close to. The traveler becomes more and more powerful and buys more and more sheep with less and less profit for the farmers. Fellow commenters and Destin, I would like you to change my view regarding how we should fight against Freebooting. I'll begin with an analogy. I think Freebooting is a lot like Movie Piracy. The reason torrents, and pirated movies are so popular among consumers is because it solves an "Availability Problem". I live outside the US and it takes ages for new TV shows to come here on DVD. But since the Internet is a thing and I know about "Game of Thrones" I solve the availability problem by downloading it off a torrent. But if I could pay for watching the same TV show live on the same day, there would be less incentive for me to download it off a torrent or visit a pirated movie store. Freebooters are the equivalent of a Pirated Movie Store for online content. They have access to a much larger consumer base than the original content producer. As a result, they are able to make profits by simply delivering freebooted content outside the producer's circle of influence. Trying to combat this situation through legal means is as hopeless as trying to stop movie piracy all around the world. So what should Destin do? Ensure his content is delivered to more people. If that involves hiring a digital marketing agency to promote his videos in previously untapped markets, then so be it. Considering the staggering number of views involved, it would be a worthwhile investment anyways. If you would like to depend on making videos for a living, you should strive to be more than just a "content producer". You should treat it like just like any other business.

@SmarterEveryDay I previously worked for Facebook (not a current FB employee), and had some involvement with video detection.  First, to be able to take down a video, they have to receive a complaint, they can't just 'know' it is copyrighted content.  They also have to verify that complaint by hand, as with all reported content - as they do not want to allow someont to be able to take down or silence someone else for something they don't like when they have no right to really do so.  If, however, Facebook is deliberately delaying this process (rather than it just taking some time due to manpower), then you are right, they should be held liable.  The person who upoaded it TO facebook however should be held liable, both in court (for copyright infringement) and by facebook (ie. having their account suspended).

Both Google and Facebook do have video detection software (based of video hashing), so this could be automated some what, however both systems are proprietary (and not compatible).  Neither company wants to just share it's hash bank of videos with the other company (no copyright implications there, just it gives the other company too much information).  As both systems are proprietary, there is no common protocol or way for each to implement a system to check the other, without having to run code created by the other company against all videos uploaded to THEIR site, and neither company wants to run some code created by the other that they cannot review or control against all videos on their systems.  I can't blame them, you may as well tell them your video volume and revenues at that point.  So the automation route is also, for now, out until one company both creates an open mechanism for doing this kind of checking, and BOTH companies agree to use it.

It's a complicated situation to try and get this to happen faster legally.  But regardless, suing the content stealer/uploader (the freebooter) is unambiguously the correct thing to do, but in many cases, you have to both be able to prove actual harm, and they can then bury you in legal costs.  So Youtube should probably step in and help their creators in this regard.

The analogy is flawed.  I'm no fan of Facebook, or even advertising in general, but this is basically the same anti-piracy argument that's been made by the likes of the RIAA, MPAA, etc. for years now.  The problem is that while sheep are a finite resource, digital video is not.  If I take your sheep, you have one less sheep, if I take your video you still have the same number of videos you had to begin with  (The story would have been more accurate if the sheep had been cloned and then eaten).

Copying a video doesn't necessarily affect (good or bad) the original content creator.  There is also a huge (and incorrect) assumption being made that had the people that viewed the video on Facebook not had such an opportunity that they would have viewed it at it's original location, where the original content creator could have profited, that isn't necessarily the case, they probably just would have never seen it at all.  

Having said all that, I still think this behavior is objectionable.  The respectable thing to do would be to link to the original video. I just also think that trying to police it is a slippery slope that eventually results in negative consequences for everyone, especially the content consumers.

Update:  Just realized that the case could also be made that the original content provider does get additional name recognition and increased subscribers from at least some of those views.  I'm just trying to say that it's far more complicated than the simple analogy presented.
